head.headtext: Search and seizure—Search by private individuals

para.paratext: A search conducted by a private individual[1] without police participation does not constitute a violation of the Fourth Amendment. In Moye v. Harper,[2] the Georgia Supreme Court held that an accused's rights were not violated when his brother searched his personal belongings, obtained handwriting samples, and gave them to police.

In Wilson v. State,[3] a lien holder's repossessor employed a locksmith to open appellant's vehicle and the repossessor inventoried its contents. The contents from the car connected the defendant with the crimes for which he was charged and tried. The Georgia Supreme Court held that there was no statutory or constitutional violation that would render the obtained evidence inadmissible at trial because this search and seizure were conducted by the repossessor of the vehicle and not by state law enforcement officers.

State v. Gasaway[4] involved an investing scheme in which the defendant's bookkeeper became suspicious and removed some of her employer's books before going to the district attorney's office to make a complaint. The Georgia Court of Appeals held that the books were removed prior to involvement of state authorities and were admissible.

Similarly, the appellate court in Hobbs v. State[5] held that state verification of evidence seized by private individuals does not constitute impermissible state involvement in the search. In Hobbs, a health club manager contacted drug task force agents after one of her employees discovered suspicious items in a club locker. The agents offered no advice, but did offer to test the substance if she brought it to them, which she did. The Georgia Court of Appeals upheld the denial of the defendant's motion to suppress because the discovery of contraband by a private citizen and its subsequent verification by police investigators did not violate the Fourth Amendment.[6]

However, see State v. Cook,[7] where the Georgia Court of Appeals upheld the grant of a motion to suppress the results of a warrantless search of a backpack, where the backpack was first searched by a hospital security guard, and later by a police deputy called in by the guard.
A comprehensive discussion of private searches is beyond the scope of this text. For a full discussion of this topic, see Daniel's Georgia Criminal Trial Practice.
Gasaway v. State, 137 Ga. App. 653, 224 S.E.2d 772 (1976).
Hobbs v. State, 272 Ga. App. 148, 611 S.E.2d 775 (2005).
